inery as will fill the building; at present it is partly
filled, and is hardly yet fairly in operation. The
engine requires the consumption Of but two feet Of
pine wood daily.

.Soves.-It has been desideratum with house,
Keepers to find some plan by which they could COM
blne the comfort OF template stove and the ecOno-
my of anth. lcite coal. II we are not deceived,
two ingenious mechanics have succeeded in supply
ing this want. We called in at the foundry, No.
a94 Market street. yesterday, and saw in full ope-
ration very simple contrivance. but one calculated
to effect much good. 1t consisted Of an iron box,
with CRATE bottom, slid into the furnace body Of
a common ten plate sove--the outward end compile
tely closing the entrance, excepting an Aperture in
the lower part of the box to admit draft Of air.
This box was filled with anthracite coal. which bur-
ned admirably, and gave more heat than is usually
impaired by the common quantity oi wood. AS
this box may be put into the stove and drawn out
with as much ease as stick of Wood. there seems
no reason why it should not be tried in fames-
the cost will he about 81 so or S2.--Our opinion


is, that it will be found to answer all the purposes 0f
family for cooking and heating roums

Meetings of the friends Of the Administration are

Perry and Cumberland, all approve the course OF
the Administration, and express determinations to
| support its policy.

EASTERN BouADARy-Ihe question relative to
our North Eastern Boundary is fast drawing to
crisis The outrages recently perpetrated by the
British authorities Of New Brunswick, are such
cannot be longer winked out of sight. 1t is time
tnr the people of this state to know that they i'll
danger Of being stripped Of one third OF their terri


tory. IL this subject has hitherto excited but little
or no interest among the people Of this state, it Isl
because the nature and extent of the British claim
has not until lately been generally understood, and
we apprehend is not now understood so generally
| AS it deserves TO be- The British claim by line
drawn from Mars Hill to the Katahdin. and from
the Katahdin by line drawn along between the
heads Of the streams which empty into the Penob-
scot and those which empty into the st. Johns, un
til it strikes the dividing line between Maine and


Lower Canada. Ii the reader will look at the map
he will see that it cats oF from Maine a territory
equal 10 the aohole Of Massachusetts,. The land it.
self it is said. exceeds III fertility am tract of equal


size within New England. Here then is the ter


ritory, capable of sustaining population OF halt


million; within the rshtful jurisdiction of Maine.


which we are in danger of having wrested from us
4 for ever.


! Our title to this country, we say, is as clear and


indisputabe as it is to any other part Of the state
4 The British may extend their claims to the kene-


bee on the same grounds precisely that they claim,


to the Penobseot and if we yield to this VIC cannot


know what pretcnces will be set up afterwards. -
i The treaty Of 1888 establishes boundary too
!, clearly to be misunderstood except by hsoe who
are determined not to understand it. The treaty


lis explicit that the people OF this state have never


supposed that it could be brought into doubt, and il
Is with us much surprise Indignation, that they
have seen the and extent OF the British CLAIM
But if the attention Of the people has been les.


directed to this ubect than its Importance deserves,


Their feelings will be aroused by AN event that has


recently occurred, in such manner that they vii
not be easily queted.


Mr.. John Baker, pea cable citizen of this state


Occupying farm which he holds under joint gran
from Massachusetts, and Maine, has been arrested
within our territorial jurisdiction by the oflcer
q of the province of New Brunswick, accompanies
e as we have understood, by armed force. aud car


ried to Fredericton, to to the British King
We have recently learnt that he has been tried, con
G ycted and sentenced to pay fine OF el50 on 5000
] and to be imprisoned for six months and that he
IS now actually ncarcera,ed under the sentence Of tn
d court in Frederickton Jail. Portland yArgos.

he fe v days, as the break In the river is complete
nd stopped, and the Tunnel free from water. T.
he Steam Engine down the shalt, draws away the d
~ in carts. as fast as the wokneu till the, by the OF
he er Arch way, which is laid within Rail Roa.i. ha
he great confidence IN its success for what is there til
IN, men cannot do, when they have at their dispos
lu- plenty Of money, and plenty of force.

of spected every thing it contained. The Armu

We are informed says the National Intelligencer.
that the favorable reception of the first volume Of A
Collection OF Debates the .dd0ptio Of the federuL
Constitutions has induced Mr.. Elliot to endeayor to

and will be published early in December pext and

lie i'll the course Of the ensuing year.


.Soves.-It has been desideratum with house,
Keepers to find some plan by which they could COM
blne the comfort OF template stove and the ecOno-
my of anth. lcite coal. II we are not deceived,
two ingenious mechanics have succeeded in supply
ing this want. We called in at the foundry, No.
a94 Market street. yesterday, and saw in full ope-
ration very simple contrivance. but one calculated
to effect much good. 1t consisted Of an iron box,
with CRATE bottom, slid into the furnace body Of
a common ten plate sove--the outward end compile
tely closing the entrance, excepting an Aperture in
the lower part of the box to admit draft Of air.
This box was filled with anthracite coal. which bur-
ned admirably, and gave more heat than is usually
impaired by the common quantity oi wood. AS
this box may be put into the stove and drawn out
with as much ease as stick of Wood. there seems
no reason why it should not be tried in fames-
the cost will he about 81 so or S2.--Our opinion


is, that it will be found to answer all the purposes 0f
family for cooking and heating roums


4 U.S. Gazette

FFOn3 ire tfutl0NW journal.


Meetings of the friends Of the Administration are
daily taking place i'll this State, with view to the
lection Of delegates to the convention winch will
be held at Harrisburg the 4th af January next
The most cheering antcipatlons are Justified by the
frequency of these meetings, and the character and
number of those by whom they are attended. 1he{
Bucks County intelIigencer received yesterday,
says =" We find it impossible to crowd within the


limits of our paper, even suanary notice OF the
numerous meetings, friendly to the Administration,
held in various parts Of this State' The resolu-
tions adopted at Montgomery, Fayete, Beaver.
Perry and Cumberland, all approve the course OF
the Administration, and express determinations to
| support its policy.


NEW JERSEY.


| numerous and respectable meeting Of gentle
men friendly to the Administration from | Of the
fourteen counties of New Jersey, took place at
rr,nton on Saturday last. William B. Ewing, Esq.
was appointed chairman. The following resolu
tions were unanimously adopted:


ResoIUed, That the adoption of vigorous and con-
certed measures be recommended to the friends OF
the Administration throughout the state, to secure
the reelection of that able statesman and patriot,
Johp O. Adams to the Presidency of the United
States.


Rosolvea, That it is the opinion of this meeting
that the friends Of the General Administration soult


hold State Convention at lrenton on the ~


day Of February next at ten clock A. M. and INA


the friends of the Administration in each township


in the state be respectfully requested to choose an'
i send two delegates to attend the state convention
III for the selection Of candidates to form ticket to
i electors of President and vice president OF the Unit


ed States, and for the adoption of such other mca
l., sures as may be deemed expedlent


J, Resolued, that the proceedings OF this meeting b
!. published by the papers friendly to the Adminisra
e ton throughout the State.


,e Nine Administration meetings, in as many di'

gates ii counties wheys lie Members of !e i.egis
atlre are known 10 Dc op,nacd 10 them.


From The 4fg.@itkltu Gazette.


HE County meeting, III Fmgi ginla tor The purpose
OF arrestlng The dangerous mai ch Of Military lanat
csin continue 10 be held with increasing spirit and
confidence. Every paper we receive from the Did
Dutnlniou brings the proceedings Of some large as
senblase Of the most intelligent citizens Of the
State reused to action by the alarming possibility Of
having their commonwealth converted into Militia
ry Dlstrict-their laws into articles Of wal--and
themselves subjected to the summary operations OF
INDEPENDENT CouRr MAR1IALs," whose bloody
decisions would be promptly executed, and whose
acts of mercy and justice would invariably be set
aside as mistaken lenty, or misconceptions of the
merits of the case. We once thought that when the
denominations were cotapleted'' Virginia would be
party; but the late glorious manifestations of her
devotion to Civil Government have SO completely
dlssipated our fears that we count upon her votes
with almost as much certainty we do upon those
of New Jersey, Ohio and Delaware.

.'Reso'"ca, That in the opinion OF this House,

Half Of the SO opponents of the resolution were

EASTERN BouADARy-Ihe question relative to
our North Eastern Boundary is fast drawing to
crisis The outrages recently perpetrated by the
British authorities Of New Brunswick, are such
cannot be longer winked out of sight. 1t is time
tnr the people of this state to know that they i'll
danger Of being stripped Of one third OF their terri


tory. IL this subject has hitherto excited but little
or no interest among the people Of this state, it Isl
because the nature and extent of the British claim
has not until lately been generally understood, and
we apprehend is not now understood so generally
| AS it deserves TO be- The British claim by line
drawn from Mars Hill to the Katahdin. and from
the Katahdin by line drawn along between the
heads Of the streams which empty into the Penob-
scot and those which empty into the st. Johns, un
til it strikes the dividing line between Maine and


Lower Canada. Ii the reader will look at the map
he will see that it cats oF from Maine a territory
equal 10 the aohole Of Massachusetts,. The land it.
self it is said. exceeds III fertility am tract of equal


size within New England. Here then is the ter


ritory, capable of sustaining population OF halt


million; within the rshtful jurisdiction of Maine.


which we are in danger of having wrested from us
4 for ever.


! Our title to this country, we say, is as clear and


indisputabe as it is to any other part Of the state
4 The British may extend their claims to the kene-


bee on the same grounds precisely that they claim,


to the Penobseot and if we yield to this VIC cannot


know what pretcnces will be set up afterwards. -
i The treaty Of 1888 establishes boundary too
!, clearly to be misunderstood except by hsoe who
are determined not to understand it. The treaty


lis explicit that the people OF this state have never


supposed that it could be brought into doubt, and il
Is with us much surprise Indignation, that they
have seen the and extent OF the British CLAIM
But if the attention Of the people has been les.


directed to this ubect than its Importance deserves,


Their feelings will be aroused by AN event that has


recently occurred, in such manner that they vii
not be easily queted.


Mr.. John Baker, pea cable citizen of this state


Occupying farm which he holds under joint gran
from Massachusetts, and Maine, has been arrested
within our territorial jurisdiction by the oflcer
q of the province of New Brunswick, accompanies
e as we have understood, by armed force. aud car


ried to Fredericton, to to the British King
We have recently learnt that he has been tried, con
G ycted and sentenced to pay fine OF el50 on 5000
] and to be imprisoned for six months and that he
IS now actually ncarcera,ed under the sentence Of tn
d court in Frederickton Jail. Portland yArgos.
